item.title: Using PlayFab for cloud gaming
item.dc:creator: Charles McKeever
item.description: In this special interview, PlayFab CEO, James Gwertzman shares insight into how this robust cloud gaming services offers value with their Game Services, Game Manager, PlayStream, and an Add-On Marketplace.
item.content:encoded:
In this special interview, PlayFab CEO, James Gwertzman shares insight into how this robust cloud gaming service offers value with their Game Services, Game Manager, and PlayStream products in addition to an add-on Marketplace. Whether you want to have back-end building blocks for your live game, empower your team with a centralized mission control, see events in real-time, or expand your game’s features while reducing SDK fatigue, PlayFab has you covered.

Thank you for watching and listening!

item.title: Corona Marketplace update – more assets!
item.dc:creator: Rob Miracle
item.description: Marketplace assets are rapidly expanding. Read on to learn about the latest additions to the Corona Marketplace.
item.content:encoded:
Over the weekend, our hard-working marketplace team slipped some amazing new assets into the Corona Marketplace. These high-quality graphic asset packs are now available for purchase, and more are on the way.

Peek in today and see all of the new game development assets which have been added!

Want to contribute?

While we finish up a few general details for assets, we invite you to submit your assets to the marketplace. We’re looking for high-quality artwork, audio, complete projects, templates, and more. Have a great animation sequence? How about some killer sprites? Have you written the perfect soundtrack? Submit your works and join the growing list of talented asset creators who are sharing their creativity with an amazing developer community!

item.title: Adding consumer brands to a skater game with Dain Hedgpeth
item.dc:creator: Charles McKeever
item.description: In this special Corona Geek podcast we talked with Dain Hedgpeth about adding consumer brands to apps. Dain's Skater game focuses on the authenticate elements of skate culture while seamlessly integrating both shoe and board brands into the game play. Hear what he would do differently if he started over today.
item.content:encoded:
In this special Corona Geek podcast we talked with Dain Hedgpeth about adding consumer brands to apps. Dain’s Skater game focuses on the authenticate elements of skate culture while  seamlessly integrating both shoe and board brands into the game play. We asked Dain to share the lessons he has learned along the way and also what he would do differently if he started over today. His answers might surprise you.

item.description: In this special Corona Geek podcast we talked with Bobby Rasmusson about developing and hand drawing hundreds of animations for his Street Puncher game. Bobby also shares what he would do differently to get featured in the app stores.
item.content:encoded:
In this special Corona Geek podcast we talked with Bobby Rasmusson about his experience developing and hand drawing hundreds of animations for his Street/ Puncher game. Bobby is a self taught animator and product manager for Lyft. During the interview, Bobby shared his experience with in-app purchases, incentivizing players to share the game, and the things he would do differently to get featured in the app stores.

item.dc:creator: Charles McKeever
item.description: In this special Corona Geek podcast we talked with Ondrej Dobsinsky about his multiplayer runner game that let's players ban abilities, "blink" to jump ahead of opponents, and includes a spectator mode so Twitch viewers can watch live tournaments.
item.content:encoded:
In this special Corona Geek podcast we talked with Ondrej Dobsinsky about his multiplayer online runner game, GetMeBro!, which also includes a spectator mode so Twitch viewers can watch live tournaments. Ondrej shares how GetMeBro! got started with just a single soundtrack and how it evolved into an addictive game that let’s players ban certain abilities to handicap other players and “blink” to jump up ahead of their opponent.

item.title: Featured App: Return to Grisly Manor
item.dc:creator: Rob Miracle
item.description: One of the earliest studios to achieve great success with Corona returns with their latest game, Return to Grisly Manor. Read on to see how Fire Maple Games continues to amaze players with beautiful, engaging adventure games.
item.content:encoded:
Corona developers everywhere continue to impress us with their creativity. Even small studios are raising the bar very high with incredible games.

One studio that continually does amazing work is Fire Maple Games. Founded by Joe Kauffman in 2008, he eventually teamed up with Pat O’Loughlin to build their first mobile adventure game, The Secret of Grisly Manor.

Return to Grisly Manor is a sequel to Fire Maple Games’ original hit which was originally designed to run on an iPhone 2G with a slow processor and limited memory. At the time, the largest app you could download over-the-air (OTA) was 20 MB. This sequel chimes in with over 2100 art assets, 320 Lua files, and 325 sound effects. With advancements in mobile hardware and removal of OTA size limits, Return to Grisly Manor is able to weigh in at four times the size of the original. All of this means that Fire Maple Games can leverage stunning images which drive amazing visual storytelling.

Since the original Grisly Manor, Fire Maple Games used Corona to produce two other outstanding adventure games. The Lost City was even more successful than Grisly Manor and it achieved the #1 paid app ranking in most countries. The Hidden World was also a commercial success, but it didn’t quite rise to the level of their previous games.

“We decided to regroup and focus our efforts, and make the next game our best, most ambitious game yet,” said Kauffman.

Return to Grisly Manor is quickly climbing the charts and getting many 5-star reviews. Just recently released in the App Store, the game already ranks in the top 20 in several countries as well as in the top 10 for both Games/Family and Games/Adventure. On Google Play, Return to Grisly Manor has a 4.9/5 rating with over 70 5-star reviews. It’s also rapidly climbing the Amazon Appstore charts.

Some history

Kauffman has long had a passion for adventure games going back to the late 1970s. He has been building adventure games since he was 12 years old, starting on a classic Macintosh with 128 KB of memory. “I want to share the joy that those games brought me with other people,” he added.

Joe and Pat both attended Millersville University in Pennsylvania where they studied fine art. Joe went on to work for Berkeley Systems on their popular screen saver software, but his love for games continued to fuel his imagination.

Kauffman found Corona shortly after Adobe switched Flash from ActionScript 2 to ActionScript 3. “I worked as a Flash developer for many years. I loved it. I was able to create anything I could imagine. When Flash switched to AS3, I felt sort of lost. I wasn’t able to do as much as I could before and it lost a lot of its fun,” he says.

“Corona was a revelation. It has the fun and ease of use of ActionScript, but it is lightning fast on mobile devices. It honestly feels like home. I can create anything I can think of. It’s wonderful,” he continued.

Conclusion

Return to Grisly Manor is available on the Apple App Store, Google Play, Amazon Appstore, and Mac App Store for $2.99.

   

Fire Maple Games and their adventure titles are a great example of using Corona to achieve success. All you need is an idea and a passion to get started. Take a moment to visit the Corona forums and congratulate Joe and Pat on their wonderful new title!
